elements.content: Presented here are two open-framework zinc phosphites, namely, Zn­(dabco)0.5(HPO3) (SCU-18) and Zn4(Hdabco)2(CH3COO)2(HPO3)4 (SCU-20), where dabco = 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]­octane. SCU-18 features a rare 3-connected inorganic skeleton with a chiral qtz-h topology. It contains 18-membered-ring (18 MR) channels displaying porosity and second-harmonic-generation response. SCU-20 has a bnn topology containing large 20 MR channels that shows a strong blue emission as a result of excitation at 375 nm.
elements.clean_text: Presented here are two open-framework zinc phosphites, namely, Zn(dabco)0.5(HPO3) (SCU-18) and Zn4(Hdabco)2(CH3COO)2(HPO3)4 (SCU-20), where dabco = 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane. SCU-18 features a rare 3-connected inorganic skeleton with a chiral qtz-h topology. It contains 18-membered-ring (18 MR) channels displaying porosity and second-harmonic-generation response. SCU-20 has a bnn topology containing large 20 MR channels that shows a strong blue emission as a result of excitation at 375 nm.

elements.content: A chiral zinc phosphite with large 18 MR channels, which displays porosity and second-harmonic-generation response, is described along with its photoluminescent open framework relative to 20 MR channels.
elements.clean_text: A chiral zinc phosphite with large 18 MR channels, which displays porosity and second-harmonic-generation response, is described along with its photoluminescent open framework relative to 20 MR channels.

elements.content: Crystalline microporous materials have been extensively studied because of their potential applications in catalysis, separation, and ion exchange. Zeolites and metal phosphate molecular sieves are the most well-known porous materials constructed from tetrahedral building blocks. Recent developments show that new framework topologies and extra-large-pore structures can be created in a metal phosphite system. Different from regular 4-connected zeolite networks, metal phosphites often possess interrupted frameworks because of the presence of HPO3 pseudopyramids as building blocks. It is believed that a HPO3 unit can reduce the M–O–P (M = metal ions) linkages and generate large-pore structures. An illustrative example is a family of bimetallic phosphites NTHU-13 with pore sizes ranging from 24-membered ring (24 MR) to 72 MR.
elements.clean_text: Crystalline microporous materials have been extensively studied because of their potential applications in catalysis, separation, and ion exchange. Zeolites and metal phosphate molecular sieves are the most well-known porous materials constructed from tetrahedral building blocks. Recent developments show that new framework topologies and extra-large-pore structures can be created in a metal phosphite system. Different from regular 4-connected zeolite networks, metal phosphites often possess interrupted frameworks because of the presence of HPO3 pseudopyramids as building blocks. It is believed that a HPO3 unit can reduce the M-O-P (M = metal ions) linkages and generate large-pore structures. An illustrative example is a family of bimetallic phosphites NTHU-13 with pore sizes ranging from 24-membered ring (24 MR) to 72 MR.

elements.content: Another way to reduce the M–O–P linkages involves the utilization of organic molecules (e.g., amines) as ligands to metal centers. It has long been known that organic ligands may play interesting structure-directing roles for the formation of open-framework structures by attachment to metal centers through M–N bonds. A notable example is the zinc phosphate NCU-1 with extra-large 28 MR channels, which contains large organic ligands within the framework. Besides the structure-directing function, organic ligands may endow the host frameworks with interesting properties such as photoluminescence (PL). However, the incorporation of organic ligands into metal phosphite frameworks often results in the formation of low-dimensional inorganic substructures. Only a few hybrid-framework metal phosphites possess 3D inorganic skeletons. The largest pore sizes of these compounds are delimited by 16 polyhedra.
elements.clean_text: Another way to reduce the M-O-P linkages involves the utilization of organic molecules (e.g., amines) as ligands to metal centers. It has long been known that organic ligands may play interesting structure-directing roles for the formation of open-framework structures by attachment to metal centers through M-N bonds. A notable example is the zinc phosphate NCU-1 with extra-large 28 MR channels, which contains large organic ligands within the framework. Besides the structure-directing function, organic ligands may endow the host frameworks with interesting properties such as photoluminescence (PL). However, the incorporation of organic ligands into metal phosphite frameworks often results in the formation of low-dimensional inorganic substructures. Only a few hybrid-framework metal phosphites possess 3D inorganic skeletons. The largest pore sizes of these compounds are delimited by 16 polyhedra.

elements.content: Here we report an amine-ligated approach for the synthesis of two open-framework zinc phosphites with extra-large channels, formulated as Zn­(dabco)0.5(HPO3) (SCU-18) and Zn4(Hdabco)2(CH3COO)2(HPO3)4 (SCU-20), where dabco = 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]­octane. Both compounds contain dabco molecules bonding to metal centers within their frameworks. Structural analysis reveals that SCU-18 features an intrinsically chiral qtz-h network with extra-large 18 MR channels, and SCU-20 has 20 MR channels containing both organic cations and anions on the walls. As far as we know, the chiral qtz-h topology was first observed in open-framework inorganic solids.
elements.clean_text: Here we report an amine-ligated approach for the synthesis of two open-framework zinc phosphites with extra-large channels, formulated as Zn(dabco)0.5(HPO3) (SCU-18) and Zn4(Hdabco)2(CH3COO)2(HPO3)4 (SCU-20), where dabco = 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane. Both compounds contain dabco molecules bonding to metal centers within their frameworks. Structural analysis reveals that SCU-18 features an intrinsically chiral qtz-h network with extra-large 18 MR channels, and SCU-20 has 20 MR channels containing both organic cations and anions on the walls. As far as we know, the chiral qtz-h topology was first observed in open-framework inorganic solids.

elements.content: Colorless crystals of SCU-18 were prepared by heating a mixture of Zn­(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.439 g), H3PO3 (0.164 g), dabco·6H2O (0.881 g), H2O (1.0 mL), and ethanol (5.0 mL) at 160 °C for 9 days (72.1% yield based on zinc). The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the resulting product is in good agreement with the simulated one on the basis of single-crystal data, indicating the phase purity of the as-synthesized compound (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information, SI). This compound remains stable up to 400 °C. The weight loss below 350 °C in its thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curve is attributed to the removal of solvent molecules in the channels (Figure S2 in the SI).
elements.clean_text: Colorless crystals of SCU-18 were prepared by heating a mixture of Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (0.439 g), H3PO3 (0.164 g), dabco⋅6H2O (0.881 g), H2O (1.0 mL), and ethanol (5.0 mL) at 160 °C for 9 days (72.1% yield based on zinc). The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the resulting product is in good agreement with the simulated one on the basis of single-crystal data, indicating the phase purity of the as-synthesized compound (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information, SI). This compound remains stable up to 400 °C. The weight loss below 350 °C in its thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curve is attributed to the removal of solvent molecules in the channels (Figure S2 in the SI).

elements.content: SCU-18 crystallizes in the trigonal space group P3221 (No. 154). The asymmetric unit contains nine non-hydrogen atoms, of which one zinc atom and one phosphorus atom are crystallographically independent. Each zinc atom is tetrahedrally coordinated by three oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom from a dabco molecule. Each phosphorus atom makes three P–O–Zn linkages to adjacent zinc atoms, with the fourth vertex occupied by a hydrogen atom. The presence of the P–H bond is confirmed by the IR spectrum, which shows a strong band at 2340 cm–1 corresponding to the stretching vibration of the phosphite P–H bond (Figure S3 in the SI).
elements.clean_text: SCU-18 crystallizes in the trigonal space group P3221 (No. 154). The asymmetric unit contains nine non-hydrogen atoms, of which one zinc atom and one phosphorus atom are crystallographically independent. Each zinc atom is tetrahedrally coordinated by three oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom from a dabco molecule. Each phosphorus atom makes three P-O-Zn linkages to adjacent zinc atoms, with the fourth vertex occupied by a hydrogen atom. The presence of the P-H bond is confirmed by the IR spectrum, which shows a strong band at 2340 cm-1 corresponding to the stretching vibration of the phosphite P-H bond (Figure S3 in the SI).

elements.content: The linkages between zinc ions and HPO3 pseudopyramids generate a 3D structure with a multidirectional pore system (a). The extra-large 18 MR channels run along the [001] direction, which are intersected by 12 MR channels running along the [100], [010], and [110] directions, respectively. The dabco molecules attach to the inorganic framework and block the 12 MR channels. Each of them connects two zinc atoms across a 12 MR window through Zn–N bonds. It should be noted that bridging amines are also observed in several 3D metal phosphites. One main function of these amines is to extend metal phosphite layers into a 3D hybrid structure. In comparison, the dabco molecules in SCU-18 act as structure-directing agents rather than bridging ligands to result in a dimensional increase.
elements.clean_text: The linkages between zinc ions and HPO3 pseudopyramids generate a 3D structure with a multidirectional pore system (a). The extra-large 18 MR channels run along the [001] direction, which are intersected by 12 MR channels running along the [100], [010], and [110] directions, respectively. The dabco molecules attach to the inorganic framework and block the 12 MR channels. Each of them connects two zinc atoms across a 12 MR window through Zn-N bonds. It should be noted that bridging amines are also observed in several 3D metal phosphites. One main function of these amines is to extend metal phosphite layers into a 3D hybrid structure. In comparison, the dabco molecules in SCU-18 act as structure-directing agents rather than bridging ligands to result in a dimensional increase.

elements.content: (a) Polyhedral representation of the framework structure of SCU-18 along the [001] direction. (b) qtz-h topological structure of the 3-connected zinc phosphite network. Color code: Zn/ZnO3N, green; P/HPO3, pink; O, red; C, gray; N, blue.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Polyhedral representation of the framework structure of SCU-18 along the [001] direction. (b) qtz-h topological structure of the 3-connected zinc phosphite network. Color code: Zn/ZnO3N, green; P/HPO3, pink; O, red; C, gray; N, blue.

elements.content: A unique structural feature of SCU-18 is its 3-connected zinc phosphite network. Topological analysis reveals that the inorganic skeleton has a qtz-h topology by regarding the zinc and phosphorus atoms as the 3-connected nodes (b). The point symbol of the inorganic network is 4.12. It is worth noting that 3-connected networks have been rarely created in 3D open-framework inorganic solids. In 2004, Zhao and co-workers reported the synthesis and structure of a fluorinated borophosphate with a 3-connected srs topology. Efforts to create 3-connected networks in metal phosphite systems often result in the formation of low-dimensional structures. Examples include the chromium phosphite (C2H10N2)­[Cr­(HPO3)­F3] with a ladderlike structure and the zinc phosphite (C5H6N2)­Zn­(HPO3) with an undulated sheet structure. The discovery of SCU-18 offers a rare example of a 3-connected metal phosphite with a 3D inorganic skeleton.
elements.clean_text: A unique structural feature of SCU-18 is its 3-connected zinc phosphite network. Topological analysis reveals that the inorganic skeleton has a qtz-h topology by regarding the zinc and phosphorus atoms as the 3-connected nodes (b). The point symbol of the inorganic network is 4.12. It is worth noting that 3-connected networks have been rarely created in 3D open-framework inorganic solids. In 2004, Zhao and co-workers reported the synthesis and structure of a fluorinated borophosphate with a 3-connected srs topology. Efforts to create 3-connected networks in metal phosphite systems often result in the formation of low-dimensional structures. Examples include the chromium phosphite (C2H10N2)[Cr(HPO3)F3] with a ladderlike structure and the zinc phosphite (C5H6N2)Zn(HPO3) with an undulated sheet structure. The discovery of SCU-18 offers a rare example of a 3-connected metal phosphite with a 3D inorganic skeleton.

elements.content: The chiral network of SCU-20 is also interesting. Most zeotpye inorganic solids reported to date are achiral because of the lack of effective ways to control the chirality. The bulk product of SCU-18 is expected to be a racemic mixture of enantiomeric crystals because all chemicals used in the solvothermal reaction are achiral. The chiral structure of SCU-18 is reminiscent of the zinc phosphite (C6H13N2)­[Zn3(C6H12N2) (HPO3)3(H2PO3)], which has extra-large 16 MR channels with dabco molecules as both ligands and countercations. It was proposed that the bonded organic molecules may play an important role in formation of the chiral structures.
elements.clean_text: The chiral network of SCU-20 is also interesting. Most zeotpye inorganic solids reported to date are achiral because of the lack of effective ways to control the chirality. The bulk product of SCU-18 is expected to be a racemic mixture of enantiomeric crystals because all chemicals used in the solvothermal reaction are achiral. The chiral structure of SCU-18 is reminiscent of the zinc phosphite (C6H13N2)[Zn3(C6H12N2) (HPO3)3(H2PO3)], which has extra-large 16 MR channels with dabco molecules as both ligands and countercations. It was proposed that the bonded organic molecules may play an important role in formation of the chiral structures.

elements.content: As expected from the coexistence of 3-connected building blocks and extra-large 18-ring channels, SCU-18 has a low framework density (FD, calculated from the number of polyhedra per 1000 Å3). The FD value is 9.9 for SCU-18, which is comparable to those observed in metal phosphites with 24 MR channels, such as 9.6 for Cr-NKU-24, 11.6 for ZnHPO-CJ1, and 11.7 for SCU-24. A void space analysis employing PLATON indicates that the free space of SCU-18 occupies 27.4% of the unit cell volume.
elements.clean_text: As expected from the coexistence of 3-connected building blocks and extra-large 18-ring channels, SCU-18 has a low framework density (FD, calculated from the number of polyhedra per 1000 Å3). The FD value is 9.9 for SCU-18, which is comparable to those observed in metal phosphites with 24 MR channels, such as 9.6 for Cr-NKU-24, 11.6 for ZnHPO-CJ1, and 11.7 for SCU-24. A void space analysis employing PLATON indicates that the free space of SCU-18 occupies 27.4% of the unit cell volume.

elements.content: To optimize the synthetic condition of SCU-18 without the addition of solvent, a mixture of Zn­(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.439 g), H3PO3 (0.164 g), and dabco·6H2O (0.221 g) was heated at 160 °C for 9 days. The reaction gave rise to colorless crystals of SCU-20 (38.3% yield based on zinc). The phase purity of the resulting product is confirmed by powder XRD analysis (Figure S4 in the SI). This compound remains stable until at least 280 °C (Figure S5 in the SI).
elements.clean_text: To optimize the synthetic condition of SCU-18 without the addition of solvent, a mixture of Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (0.439 g), H3PO3 (0.164 g), and dabco⋅6H2O (0.221 g) was heated at 160 °C for 9 days. The reaction gave rise to colorless crystals of SCU-20 (38.3% yield based on zinc). The phase purity of the resulting product is confirmed by powder XRD analysis (Figure S4 in the SI). This compound remains stable until at least 280 °C (Figure S5 in the SI).

elements.content: SCU-20 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ (No. 2). It has a new 3D structure constructed from two different cyclic secondary building units: a Zn2(HPO3)2 cluster (denoted as S4R) and a Zn3(HPO3)3 cluster (denoted as S6R), as shown in a. Each S6R unit connects four adjacent neighbors to form a layered structure with 4, 6, and 8 MR windows. The zinc phosphite layers are parallel to the ab plane, which are further bridged by S4R units to give rise to a 3D structure (b). The S4R to S6R ratio is 1:2. When S6R units are regarded as the nodes and S4R units as the linkers, the structure can be simplified as a 5-connected bnn network (c). The FD of SCU-20 is 10.6 polyhedra per 1000 Å3.
elements.clean_text: SCU-20 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ (No. 2). It has a new 3D structure constructed from two different cyclic secondary building units: a Zn2(HPO3)2 cluster (denoted as S4R) and a Zn3(HPO3)3 cluster (denoted as S6R), as shown in a. Each S6R unit connects four adjacent neighbors to form a layered structure with 4, 6, and 8 MR windows. The zinc phosphite layers are parallel to the ab plane, which are further bridged by S4R units to give rise to a 3D structure (b). The S4R to S6R ratio is 1:2. When S6R units are regarded as the nodes and S4R units as the linkers, the structure can be simplified as a 5-connected bnn network (c). The FD of SCU-20 is 10.6 polyhedra per 1000 Å3.

elements.content: (a) Polyhedral representation of the S4R and S6R building blocks. (b) View of the framework structure of SCU-20 along the [100] direction. (c) bnn topology of SCU-20.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Polyhedral representation of the S4R and S6R building blocks. (b) View of the framework structure of SCU-20 along the [100] direction. (c) bnn topology of SCU-20.

elements.content: As viewed along the [100] direction, SCU-20 displays extra-large 20 MR channels. Both organic cations (i.e., Hdabco) and anions (i.e., acetate) attach to the walls through Zn–N­(O) bonds. Each S4R unit contains four acetate anions, and each S6R unit contains two Hdabco cations. The organic species may act as cotemplating agents for formation of the open-framework structure. Previously, amines are always incorporated into neutral metal phosphite frameworks in their electrically neutral forms. For metal phosphites with macroanionic networks, protonated amine molecules may be combined with inorganic frameworks to meet the global charge balance. It is believed that the hybrid framework consisting of both protonated amine molecules and a neutral inorganic skeleton is unstable. In the present work, the presence of acetate anions makes it possible to incorporate ammonium cations into the neutral metal phosphite framework of SCU-20.
elements.clean_text: As viewed along the [100] direction, SCU-20 displays extra-large 20 MR channels. Both organic cations (i.e., Hdabco) and anions (i.e., acetate) attach to the walls through Zn-N(O) bonds. Each S4R unit contains four acetate anions, and each S6R unit contains two Hdabco cations. The organic species may act as cotemplating agents for formation of the open-framework structure. Previously, amines are always incorporated into neutral metal phosphite frameworks in their electrically neutral forms. For metal phosphites with macroanionic networks, protonated amine molecules may be combined with inorganic frameworks to meet the global charge balance. It is believed that the hybrid framework consisting of both protonated amine molecules and a neutral inorganic skeleton is unstable. In the present work, the presence of acetate anions makes it possible to incorporate ammonium cations into the neutral metal phosphite framework of SCU-20.

elements.content: To confirm the porosity of SCU-18, N2 adsorption measurement was carried out at −196 °C. Prior to the measurement, the polycrystalline sample was degassed overnight at 150 °C. N2 adsorption results indicate that the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area of SCU-18 was calculated to be 37.8 m2 g–1 (Figure S7 in the SI). This compound can adsorb 28.7 cm3 g–1 H2 at 1.0 atm and 77 K (Figure S8 in the SI). The second-harmonic-generation (SHG) measurement for SCU-18 was carried out on its powder sample by the Kurtz–Perry method at room temperature. The intensity of the green light (frequency-doubled output: 532 nm) produced by the sample exhibits a SHG efficiency of about 0.4 times that of the KDP (KH2PO4) powder (a), confirming the absence of a center of symmetry for this compound. Upon excitation at 375 nm, SCU-20 displayed a strong blue luminescence with a peak maximum at ca. 450 nm (b). For SCU-18, no fluorescent response was observed in the measured region under the experimental conditions.
elements.clean_text: To confirm the porosity of SCU-18, N2 adsorption measurement was carried out at -196 °C. Prior to the measurement, the polycrystalline sample was degassed overnight at 150 °C. N2 adsorption results indicate that the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area of SCU-18 was calculated to be 37.8 m2 g-1 (Figure S7 in the SI). This compound can adsorb 28.7 cm3 g-1 H2 at 1.0 atm and 77 K (Figure S8 in the SI). The second-harmonic-generation (SHG) measurement for SCU-18 was carried out on its powder sample by the Kurtz-Perry method at room temperature. The intensity of the green light (frequency-doubled output: 532 nm) produced by the sample exhibits a SHG efficiency of about 0.4 times that of the KDP (KH2PO4) powder (a), confirming the absence of a center of symmetry for this compound. Upon excitation at 375 nm, SCU-20 displayed a strong blue luminescence with a peak maximum at ca. 450 nm (b). For SCU-18, no fluorescent response was observed in the measured region under the experimental conditions.

elements.content: (a) Comparison of the measured SHG response of SCU-18 with that of KDP. (b) PL excitation (dotted line) and emission (solid line) spectra of SCU-20 at room temperature. Inset: Photograph of crystals of SCU-20 under excitation of 365 nm UV light.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Comparison of the measured SHG response of SCU-18 with that of KDP. (b) PL excitation (dotted line) and emission (solid line) spectra of SCU-20 at room temperature. Inset: Photograph of crystals of SCU-20 under excitation of 365 nm UV light.

elements.content: In summary, two new zinc phosphites with extra-large channels were synthesized by an amine-ligated approach. The coexistence of extra-large 18 MR channels, an intrinsically chiral topology, and a 3-connected inorganic network in the same crystalline structure is observed for the first time in zeotype materials. Furthermore, the synergetic templating effect of organic cations and anions may offer new possibilities in the devolopment of hybrid open-framework solids.
elements.clean_text: In summary, two new zinc phosphites with extra-large channels were synthesized by an amine-ligated approach. The coexistence of extra-large 18 MR channels, an intrinsically chiral topology, and a 3-connected inorganic network in the same crystalline structure is observed for the first time in zeotype materials. Furthermore, the synergetic templating effect of organic cations and anions may offer new possibilities in the devolopment of hybrid open-framework solids.

References

Crystal data for SCU-18: C3H7NO3PZn, trigonal, space group P3221 (No. 154), a = 10.1988 (1) Å, c = 13.4856(3) Å, V = 1214.78(4) Å3, Z = 6, Flack parameter = −0.01(4), D c = 1.652 g cm–3, μ = 5.694 mm–1, 5803 reflections measured, 1444 unique (R int = 0.0402). Final wR2 (all data) = 0.1982 and final R1 = 0.0669. Crystal data for SCU-20: C16H36N4O16P4Zn4, triclinic, space group P1̅ (No. 2), a = 8.7793(3) Å, b = 9.9952(2) Å, c = 17.6047(6) Å, α = 83.642(2)°, β = 81.302(3)°, γ = 86.406(2)°, V = 1516.01(8) Å3, Z = 2, D c = 2.028 g cm–3, μ = 6.293 mm–1, 15943 reflections measured, 5412 unique (R int = 0.0393). Final wR2 (all data) = 0.1214 and final R1 = 0.0441.

cln_elements.content:
Colorless crystals of SCU-18 were prepared by heating a mixture of Zn­(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.439 g), H3PO3 (0.164 g), dabco·6H2O (0.881 g), H2O (1.0 mL), and ethanol (5.0 mL) at 160 °C for 9 days (72.1% yield based on zinc). The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the resulting product is in good agreement with the simulated one on the basis of single-crystal data, indicating the phase purity of the as-synthesized compound (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information, SI). This compound remains stable up to 400 °C. The weight loss below 350 °C in its thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curve is attributed to the removal of solvent molecules in the channels (Figure S2 in the SI).

To optimize the synthetic condition of SCU-18 without the addition of solvent, a mixture of Zn­(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.439 g), H3PO3 (0.164 g), and dabco·6H2O (0.221 g) was heated at 160 °C for 9 days. The reaction gave rise to colorless crystals of SCU-20 (38.3% yield based on zinc). The phase purity of the resulting product is confirmed by powder XRD analysis (Figure S4 in the SI). This compound remains stable until at least 280 °C (Figure S5 in the SI).

The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the resulting product is in good agreement with the simulated one on the basis of single-crystal data, indicating the phase purity of the as-synthesized compound (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information, SI). This compound remains stable up to 400 °C. The weight loss below 350 °C in its thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curve is attributed to the removal of solvent molecules in the channels (Figure S2 in the SI).

To optimize the synthetic condition of SCU-18 without the addition of solvent, a mixture of Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (0.439 g), H3PO3 (0.164 g), and dabco⋅6H2O (0.221 g) was heated at 160 °C for 9 days. The reaction gave rise to colorless crystals of SCU-20 (38.3% yield based on zinc). The phase purity of the resulting product is confirmed by powder XRD analysis (Figure S4 in the SI). intermediate_step.text-synthesis-struct:

cln_elements.content:
As expected from the coexistence of 3-connected building blocks and extra-large 18-ring channels, SCU-18 has a low framework density (FD, calculated from the number of polyhedra per 1000 Å3). The FD value is 9.9 for SCU-18, which is comparable to those observed in metal phosphites with 24 MR channels, such as 9.6 for Cr-NKU-24, 11.6 for ZnHPO-CJ1, and 11.7 for SCU-24. A void space analysis employing PLATON indicates that the free space of SCU-18 occupies 27.4% of the unit cell volume.

SCU-20 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ (No. 2). It has a new 3D structure constructed from two different cyclic secondary building units: a Zn2(HPO3)2 cluster (denoted as S4R) and a Zn3(HPO3)3 cluster (denoted as S6R), as shown in a. Each S6R unit connects four adjacent neighbors to form a layered structure with 4, 6, and 8 MR windows. The zinc phosphite layers are parallel to the ab plane, which are further bridged by S4R units to give rise to a 3D structure (b). The S4R to S6R ratio is 1:2. When S6R units are regarded as the nodes and S4R units as the linkers, the structure can be simplified as a 5-connected bnn network (c). The FD of SCU-20 is 10.6 polyhedra per 1000 Å3.

To confirm the porosity of SCU-18, N2 adsorption measurement was carried out at −196 °C. Prior to the measurement, the polycrystalline sample was degassed overnight at 150 °C. N2 adsorption results indicate that the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area of SCU-18 was calculated to be 37.8 m2 g–1 (Figure S7 in the SI). This compound can adsorb 28.7 cm3 g–1 H2 at 1.0 atm and 77 K (Figure S8 in the SI). The second-harmonic-generation (SHG) measurement for SCU-18 was carried out on its powder sample by the Kurtz–Perry method at room temperature. The intensity of the green light (frequency-doubled output: 532 nm) produced by the sample exhibits a SHG efficiency of about 0.4 times that of the KDP (KH2PO4) powder (a), confirming the absence of a center of symmetry for this compound. Upon excitation at 375 nm, SCU-20 displayed a strong blue luminescence with a peak maximum at ca. 450 nm (b). For SCU-18, no fluorescent response was observed in the measured region under the experimental conditions.

As expected from the coexistence of 3-connected building blocks and extra-large 18-ring channels, SCU-18 has a low framework density (FD, calculated from the number of polyhedra per 1000 Å3). The FD value is 9.9 for SCU-18, which is comparable to those observed in metal phosphites with 24 MR channels, such as 9.6 for Cr-NKU-24, 11.6 for ZnHPO-CJ1, and 11.7 for SCU-24. A void space analysis employing PLATON indicates that the free space of SCU-18 occupies 27.4% of the unit cell volume. 

SCU-20 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ (No. 2). It has a new 3D structure constructed from two different cyclic secondary building units: a Zn2(HPO3)2 cluster (denoted as S4R) and a Zn3(HPO3)3 cluster (denoted as S6R), as shown in a. Each S6R unit connects four adjacent neighbors to form a layered structure with 4, 6, and 8 MR windows. The zinc phosphite layers are parallel to the ab plane, which are further bridged by S4R units to give rise to a 3D structure (b). The S4R to S6R ratio is 1:2. When S6R units are regarded as the nodes and S4R units as the linkers, the structure can be simplified as a 5-connected bnn network (c). The FD of SCU-20 is 10.6 polyhedra per 1000 Å3.

To confirm the porosity of SCU-18, N2 adsorption measurement was carried out at -196 °C. Prior to the measurement, the polycrystalline sample was degassed overnight at 150 °C. N2 adsorption results indicate that the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area of SCU-18 was calculated to be 37.8 m2 g-1 (Figure S7 in the SI). This compound can adsorb 28.7 cm3 g-1 H2 at 1.0 atm and 77 K (Figure S8 in the SI). The second-harmonic-generation (SHG) measurement for SCU-18 was carried out on its powder sample by the Kurtz-Perry method at room temperature. The intensity of the green light (frequency-doubled output: 532 nm) produced by the sample exhibits a SHG efficiency of about 0.4 times that of the KDP (KH2PO4) powder (a), confirming the absence of a center of symmetry for this compound. Upon excitation at 375 nm, SCU-20 displayed a strong blue luminescence with a peak maximum at ca. 450 nm (b). For SCU-18, no fluorescent response was observed in the measured region under the experimental conditions.

etc.unit: times that of the KDP (KH2PO4) powder

etc.condition: excitation at 375 nm, peak maximum at ca. 450 nm

cln_elements.content: (a) Polyhedral representation of the framework structure of SCU-18 along the [001] direction. (b) qtz-h topological structure of the 3-connected zinc phosphite network. Color code: Zn/ZnO3N, green; P/HPO3, pink; O, red; C, gray; N, blue.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Polyhedral representation of the framework structure of SCU-18 along the [001] direction. (b) qtz-h topological structure of the 3-connected zinc phosphite network. Color code: Zn/ZnO3N, green; P/HPO3, pink; O, red; C, gray; N, blue.

cln_elements.content: (a) Polyhedral representation of the S4R and S6R building blocks. (b) View of the framework structure of SCU-20 along the [100] direction. (c) bnn topology of SCU-20.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Polyhedral representation of the S4R and S6R building blocks. (b) View of the framework structure of SCU-20 along the [100] direction. (c) bnn topology of SCU-20.

cln_elements.content: (a) Comparison of the measured SHG response of SCU-18 with that of KDP. (b) PL excitation (dotted line) and emission (solid line) spectra of SCU-20 at room temperature. Inset: Photograph of crystals of SCU-20 under excitation of 365 nm UV light.

metadata.title:
Amine-Ligated Approach for the Synthesis of Extra-Large-Pore
Zinc Phosphites with qtz‑h and bnn Topologies
